Uprisings As Much Economic As Political
DOC.TEXT: The fury of Romanians against their former government is revealed partly by the economic statistics. Romania, in recent years, has been the economic backwater of Eastern Europe. Alone among those nations _ Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary and Poland _ the country's gross national product and industrial production declined in 1988. Its GNP last year, in fact, was about where it was in 1980, while almost every other developed nation, communist and non-communist, registered increases. In that time China more than doubled its GNP. While Romania's neighbors increased exports between 1980 and 1986, its exports stagnated. Romania's population of 23 million is exceeded only by that of Poland, but Romania's imports were lower than any fraternal East Bloc country. Its per capita gross national product of $5,500 also remains the lowest in Eastern Europe, less than one-half that of East Germany, and it is falling. Whereas East Germans had an automobile-to-population ratio of one to five, in Romania the ratio was just a bit more than one in 100. While Romanian meat production averaged 70 kilograms per capita, that of Hungary was 160. In effect, the old government was leading the nation into economic decline and lower living standards at a time when growth, if perhaps slowly, was the rule in every other European country, possibly excluding tiny Albania. The profile of economic deterioration amid growth emerges from research completed in August and published in September by the Central Intelligence Agency. It shows a vivid contrast between communist and capitalist nations. The figures also suggest the urgent need of the Soviet Union to renovate and spur its own economy, in which growth rates have steadily deteriorated in recent years. The CIA research shows Soviet GNP falling from average annual growth of 4.8 percent in 1961-65 and 4.9 percent from 1966-70, to 3.1 percent in 1971-75, 2.1 percent in 1976-80 and 1.9 percent in 1981-85. After a 4 percent spurt in 1986, mainly the result of a 10.3 percent surge in agricultural production, the GNP growth rate subsided to 1.3 percent in 1987 and 1.5 percent in 1988. Agricultural production shrank in the latter years. Reviewing the numbers, and contrasting them with those of the capitalist world, it's clear that the economies of the communist countries as a whole were becoming outmatched. In 1988, the annual rate of GNP growth in the United States, Canada, Japan, Australia and all countries of Western Europe, Yugoslavia excepted, exceeded that of the Soviet Union and the Soviet bloc nations of Eastern Europe. Even the economies of the less developed countries, taken as a whole, showed a growth rate of 3.7 percent, or higher than the Soviet Union and the Communists nations of Eastern Europe. Among the large communist nations, a swiftly industrializing China stands out, registering a growth rate of 11.2 percent in 1988, the third time since 1983 in which it has reached double-digit levels. The stark contrast between the communist and non-communist nations that emerges from the data emphasizes the economic origins of the upheavals. In an age of developing communications, that contrast was obvious to all, except perhaps for a few leaders.
